newsitem.title: UK: Kirkuk winning April Med battle, faces tougher May.
newsitem.headline: Kirkuk winning April Med battle, faces tougher May.

text.p: Iraq's Kirkuk crude oil could face tough competition from Urals in May but may well get the better of its Russian rival in the short term, traders said on Monday.
An improvement in refinery margins and a firm contango in prices should keep Mediterranean demand healthy for Kirkuk, loaded from the Turkish port of Ceyhan, in the next week or two.

But a fall in the Urals price in the run-up to May resulting from a rise in Mediterranean sour supply would likely squeeze Kirkuk painfully -- unless the United Nations could be persuaded to allow another adjustment in Iraqi pricing, they said.
"In the short term, with Urals anywhere above Dated -$1.50 or $1.60, Kirkuk is good value and people will lift on term," a trader said.
"But with Urals any lower Kirkuk is in trouble. And in May there will be plenty of oil around."
Urals was valued around Dated Brent -$1.40 a barrel, cif Augusta, on Friday.
Iraq is currently selling oil in the second 90-day period of its six-month oil-for-food deal, which started on December 10 and will end on June 7.
Under the deal, Iraq is allowed to sell $2 billion worth of crude over six months to buy food and medicine for Iraqis suffering under sanctions imposed in 1990 after its invasion of Kuwait.
Kirkuk for sale into Europe in May will be priced at Dated Brent less $2.20 a barrel, a 30-cent cut from April.
At that level traders see Kirkuk easily finding homes in preference to Urals at current levels of Dated -$1.40.
Kirkuk's May level represents a notional price differential to Urals of around 80 cents, a substantial erosion of around 50 percent in Urals' recent price competitiveness.
But Kirkuk's April loading programme of an initial 430,000 barrels per day (bpd) is a substantial 35-40 percent increase from around 310,000 bpd in February and March and could easily go higher.
And in late April, Urals' May programme will be looming on the horizon, in contrast to the current situation where Urals cargoes are available but not plentiful.

"Kirkuk will have a fairly smooth run from the contango and increased refinery offtake until we go beyond around May 5," a trader said. "But once we start selling Urals in the third decade of April for barrels loading in early May the market will come off. Frankly I see Urals in June down to Dated -$1.90."
The Kirkuk price cut was made possible by an equivalent reduction for May in the European price of Saudi Arab Light.
Kirkuk is priced against Arab light cent-for-cent under arrangements established by the United Nations as part of the oil-for-food programme.
Other analysts say Kirkuk and fellow Iraqi crude Basrah will feel some benefit from rising global demand as refineries come out of spring maintenance.
"By end-April we'll have seen the low point in refinery demand," an oil analyst said. "European maintenance equivalent to around one million bpd will be coming to an end by May."

In Asia between 1.7 million and two million bpd of capacity will be in turnaround in May and June, but since Asian buying of Middle East crude has a two-month delivery window, demand for July will already be feeding through this month, analysts say.

More support could arise from uncertainty about whether a second six months of oil-for-food will be approved by the U.N. Security Council. "If there is any doubt then there could be some tightness," a trader said.
At current prices, Iraq would earn up to $950 million in the second 90 days if it pumps around 430,000 bpd of Kirkuk and 300,000 bpd of Basrah in April and May, according to industry estimates.

But a further threat to Kirkuk comes indirectly from its present pricing structure -- Baghdad may react to the prospect of weaker May prices by selling more to meet its cash target, and by doing so help weaken the market further.
Brent crude lost another 50 cents a barrel on Friday, extending its three-month slide to over $7. Dated Brent was worth around $16.78 a barrel, its lowest level in over 12 months.
As long as Iraq must operate under a revenue ceiling in a weak market, sales increases are likely to chase falling prices in a vicious circle that squeezes value out of the barrel.
-- William Maclean London newsroom +44 171 542 7646
